body:
I can't load the Lmod module for `bat` (a cat(1) replacement, written in Rust, PR pending #10837).

I think that there's an inconsistency where Spack isn't seeing `llvm` as a compiler but the modules we generate *is*.

I'd love to understand the current state of the art around compilers but would be content to remain ignorant if I end up with a way to load my `gcc` built `emacs` alongside a `rust` -> `llvm` -> `gcc` built `bat`.

This may or may not be related to #3973.

---

I'm working on a CentOS 7 system, which provides `gcc@4.8.5`.

I use that to build `gcc@8.2.0` and set that as the default compiler via `packages.yaml`.

My `etc/spack/modules.yaml` file lists `gcc@4.8.5` in `core_compilers`.

I then ran `spack install rust` and `spack install bat` (a cat(1) replacement, written in Rust, PR pending #10837).  Rust is built w/ `llvm`, which ends up being built with `gcc@8.2.0` in my configuration.

`bat` ends up linking to the following dynamic libraries:

```consolesession
[ghartzell@bifx1n03 spack]$ ldd /home/ghartzell/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-8.2.0/bat-0.10.0-xldouz3jymfgh7whohqgfxhvkebnejgf/bin/bat
        linux-vdso.so.1 =>  (0x00007ffd0cdfd000)
        libz.so.1 => /home/ghartzell/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-8.2.0/zlib-1.2.11-6wdekzyadff6repdb5bxinnzizvnn35t/lib/libz.so.1 (0x00007f0569786000)
        libc.so.6 => /lib64/libc.so.6 (0x00007f05693b9000)
        /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f056a085000)
        libdl.so.2 => /lib64/libdl.so.2 (0x00007f05691b5000)
        libpthread.so.0 => /lib64/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f0568f99000)
        libgcc_s.so.1 => /home/ghartzell/spack/opt/spack/linux-centos7-x86_64/gcc-4.8.5/gcc-8.2.0-uc6sbumioobdbkw4rwfyn2givi4nyvwq/lib64/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f0568d81000)
        libm.so.6 => /lib64/libm.so.6 (0x00007f0568a7f000)
[ghartzell@bifx1n03 spack]$
```

I'm running into two problems with Lmod and hierarchical modules:

1. [this is probably a philosophical/meta-issue] There doesn't appear to be any way to use `llvm` built binaries (e.g. `bat`) and `gcc` built binaries simultaneously, even though things are either statically linked or RPATH'ed.  Perhaps this means that I should give up on Lmod?

2. I seem to be unable to load the `bat` module, because (I think) Spack doesn't consider `llvm` a core compiler but the Lmod module files do (the `llvm` modulefile includes a `family("compiler")` statement).

    ```consolesession
    $ module load gcc
    $ module load aspell direnv emacs git htop r the-silver-searcher tmux tree vim
    $ module load bat

    Lmod is automatically replacing "gcc/8.2.0-uc6sbum" with "llvm/7.0.1-py2.7-e3eu7bx".


    Inactive Modules:
      1) aspell                        14) glib/2.56.3-py3.6-zypsii3                     27) libiconv/1.15-q7w32zb           40) libxrender/0.9.10-sctxcs3     53) tar/1.31-t2cmxty
      2) bzip2/1.0.6-7djguhm           15) gmp/6.1.2-yhxishz                             28) libjpeg-turbo/1.5.90-aq4xone    41) libxt/1.1.5-yo5j5vj           54) tcl/8.6.8-fi32equ
      3) cairo/1.16.0-py3.6-ma44jfg    16) gnutls/3.5.13-apvnfcf                         29) libpng/1.6.34-nu6yixy           42) ncurses/6.1-i655y27           55) the-silver-searcher
      4) curl/7.63.0-5atszob           17) gobject-introspection/1.56.1-py3.6-3dzsuht    30) libpthread-stubs/0.4-bsy6nqs    43) nettle/3.4-vft434l            56) tk/8.6.8-ekmkqhf
      5) direnv                        18) harfbuzz/2.3.1-py3.6-oi2acur                  31) libsm/1.2.2-o2oh3wn             44) openssl/1.1.1b-ttpynn6        57) tmux
      6) emacs                         19) htop                                          32) libtiff/4.0.9-vntoozu           45) pango/1.41.0-py3.6-r63ixek    58) tree
      7) expat/2.2.5-yueu76y           20) icu4c/60.1-yaq7rkn                            33) libx11/1.6.7-fde7vhi            46) pcre/8.42-jit-5sg6h5n         59) vim
      8) font-util/1.3.1-h55nsu2       21) jdk/1.8.0_141-b15-npe2acp                     34) libxau/1.0.8-agyejqp            47) perl/5.26.2-ndoqgto           60) xextproto/7.3.0-lk677zo
      9) fontconfig/2.12.3-k6alczn     22) kbproto/1.0.7-2vjelnv                         35) libxcb/1.13-be6phqf             48) pixman/0.38.0-har4ax3         61) xproto/7.0.31-3wym7qv
     10) freetype/2.9.1-zxaa544        23) libbsd/0.9.1-64drktg                          36) libxdmcp/1.1.2-foxpnlx          49) r                             62) xz/5.2.4-fvj6toh
     11) gdbm/1.18.1-2ggaajb           24) libevent/2.1.8-sxsgzkp                        37) libxext/1.3.3-m5gjspr           50) readline/7.0-wcnxwmb          63) zlib/1.2.11-6wdekzy
     12) gettext/0.19.8.1-c6ipolx      25) libffi/3.2.1-2ssqtqu                          38) libxft/2.3.2-kcv646d            51) renderproto/0.11.1-cjz4unl
     13) git                           26) libice/1.0.9-dfwj5jo                          39) libxml2/2.9.8-z2gjacs           52) sqlite/3.26.0-s5v72k5

    $ which bat
    /usr/bin/which: no bat in (/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/sbin)
    $ module load bat
    Lmod has detected the following error:  These module(s) exist but cannot be loaded as requested: "bat"
       Try: "module spider bat" to see how to load the module(s).



    $ module spider bat

    ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
      bat: bat/0.10.0-py2.7-xldouz3
    ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

        You will need to load all module(s) on any one of the lines below before the "bat/0.10.0-py2.7-xldouz3" module is available to load.

      gcc/8.2.0-uc6sbum

        Help:
          A cat(1) clone with wings.

    $
    ```

Spack considers `bat` to "belong" to gcc@8.2.0 (as seen in `spack find`) and drops the modulefile into the `gcc/8.2.0` directory.  But, when I load it, it `rust` which loads `llvm` and (I think) the `family("compiler")` bit causes Lmod to unload `gcc/8.2.0` and try to load a Core modulefile for `llvm` (which doesn't exist).

I also tried building the system compiler (via `spack install bat%gcc@4.8.5`), which built `llvm` with `gcc@4.8.5` and then built rust with that `llvm` and finally `bat` with that `rust`.

I still only have one Core modulefile, for `gcc@8.2.0`, which confuses me.  Trying to refer to `llvm` as a compiler, e.g. 


```consolesession
$ spack spec bat%llvm
Input spec
--------------------------------
bat%llvm

Concretized
--------------------------------
==> Error: The 'llvm' compiler is not yet supported.
```

makes it seem that `llvm` isn't a first class citizen.  I've also used `spack compiler add ...` to add the llvm compiler but still end up painted into the same corner.  And, I've tried adding `llvm` as a core compiler in my `modules.yaml` without any joy.

As mentioned up top, I'd love to understand the current state of the art around compilers but would be content to remain ignorant if I end up with a way to load my `gcc` built `emacs` alongside a `rust` -> `llvm` -> `gcc` built `bat`.
title: Lmod, gcc, llvm, rust -> can't load Lmod module
